page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 115: Line 115:
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref name="Ahram08">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref name="Ahram08">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
â
A ''Facebook'' page entitled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" read: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref name="memri1">{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> On 1 July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered for what they termed the '''"Friday of Retribution"'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/thousands-demonstrate-on-friday-of-retribution.html |title=Thousands demonstrate on 'Friday of Retribution' |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change five months after Mubarak's ousting<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
+
A ''Facebook'' page entitled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" read: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref name="memri1">{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> On 1 July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered for what they termed the '''"Friday of Retribution"'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/thousands-demonstrate-on-friday-of-retribution.html |title=Thousands demonstrate on 'Friday of Retribution' |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change five months after Mubarak's ousting<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
On 4 July, an explosion at the [[Arab Gas Pipeline|pipeline]] near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] haltied natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. This was the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since Mubarak ouster.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref>
On 4 July, an explosion at the [[Arab Gas Pipeline|pipeline]] near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] haltied natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. This was the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since Mubarak ouster.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref>
Line 121: Line 121:
On 8 July, hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered for what they called the '''"Friday of Determination"'''<ref name="Ahram08"/> or '''"March of the Million"''' again in Suez, Alexandria, Tahrir Square in Cairo and other cities{{which}} demanding immediate reforms and swifter [[Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution|prosecution of former officials]] from the former government of Hosni Mubarak.
On 8 July, hundreds of thousands of protesters gathered for what they called the '''"Friday of Determination"'''<ref name="Ahram08"/> or '''"March of the Million"''' again in Suez, Alexandria, Tahrir Square in Cairo and other cities{{which}} demanding immediate reforms and swifter [[Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution|prosecution of former officials]] from the former government of Hosni Mubarak.
â
Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|banning the trail of civilians by military courts]]; setting a minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons and the senior officials to speedy trials; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils, stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel,<ref name="memri1"/> quick trials of police officers responsible for killing the protesters during the early days of the revolution and restructuring the ministry of interior and cleansing the police force. An employee of [[Suez Canal University]] said that, before coming to Cairo, in [[Ismailiya]] there were also protests for higher wages and stable employment contracts.<ref name="englishahram"/> Protesters also called for the ouster of [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] as emblematic of the old regime.<Ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html</ref>
+
Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|banning the trail of civilians by military courts]]; setting a minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons and the senior officials to speedy trials; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils, stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel,<ref name="memri1"/> quick trials of police officers responsible for killing the protesters during the early days of the revolution and restructuring the ministry of interior and cleansing the police force. An employee of [[Suez Canal University]] said that, before coming to Cairo, in [[Ismailiya]] there were also protests for higher wages and stable employment contracts.<ref name="englishahram"/> Protesters also called for the ouster of [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] as emblematic of the old regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
â
In organising the protests several stages had been set up by various political groups: the Revolution Youth Coalition, a coalition of liberal parties and movements,{{which}}, the Muslim Brotherhood, the Wafd party and leftist parties.{{which}} As the Muslim Brotherhoodâs stage was the highest and biggest, many protesters complained that they were attempting to steal the show. This was in addition to the Muslim Brotherhood's opposition to a sit-in called by other political groups to pressure the Supreme Council of Armed Forces into meeting their demands. Though the Muslim Brotherhood decided to join the protests only two days before the event, it said that it would avoid the sit-in and leave by 17:00. The event was used to rally support for the various groups by organising their own tents and passing out paraphenilia.<ref name="englishahram">http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx</ref>
+
In organising the protests several stages had been set up by various political groups: the Revolution Youth Coalition, a coalition of liberal parties and movements,{{which}}, the Muslim Brotherhood, the Wafd party and leftist parties.{{which}} As the Muslim Brotherhoodâs stage was the highest and biggest, many protesters complained that they were attempting to steal the show. This was in addition to the Muslim Brotherhood's opposition to a sit-in called by other political groups to pressure the Supreme Council of Armed Forces into meeting their demands. Though the Muslim Brotherhood decided to join the protests only two days before the event, it said that it would avoid the sit-in and leave by 17:00. The event was used to rally support for the various groups by organising their own tents and passing out paraphenilia.<ref name="englishahram">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>
